metadata.Description: Tidal power is a form of hydropower that converts the energy from the tides into electricity.

entities.Description: Markets where electricity, natural gas, and other energy commodities are bought and sold.
Tidal power is a form of hydropower that converts the energy from the tides into electricity.
Agencies that promote and support the development and use of renewable energy sources.
The use of less energy to provide the same level of output or service, resulting in reduced energy consumption, cost savings, and environmental benefits.
A concept that aims to ensure a fair and equitable transition to a sustainable energy system, taking into account social, economic, and environmental aspects.
Cogeneration, also known as combined heat and power (CHP), is the simultaneous production of electricity and useful heat from the same energy source.
The process of capturing and storing energy for later use.
Renewable energy certificates, also known as green certificates or tradable renewable certificates, are proof that a certain amount of electricity has been generated from renewable sources.

relations.Subject: cogeneration
relations.Description: Cogeneration implements the Energy Efficiency Policy by generating electricity and useful heat simultaneously, resulting in higher energy efficiency.

relations.Subject: cogeneration
relations.Description: Cogeneration is commonly used in the industrial sector to meet the energy demands of manufacturing processes and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

relations.Subject: energy storage
relations.Description: Energy storage addresses the issue of intermittency in renewable energy sources by storing excess energy for use during periods of low generation.

relations.Subject: energy markets
relations.Description: Energy markets address the issue of energy access by ensuring the availability and affordability of energy sources for all segments of society.

relations.Subject: renewable energy certificates
relations.Description: Renewable energy certificates are implemented by the Energy Efficiency Policy to promote the use of renewable energy sources.

relations.Subject: energy efficiency

Tidal turbines are devices that convert the kinetic energy of tidal currents into electrical energy. They are typically installed on the seabed or mounted on floating platforms and use the flow of water to rotate their blades and generate electricity.
relations.Subject: tidal turbines

relations.Description: Tidal barrages are large structures built across estuaries or bays to capture and harness the energy of tidal movements. They consist of a dam-like barrier with turbines that generate electricity as the tide flows in and out, utilizing the potential energy difference between high and low tides.
relations.Subject: tidal barrages

relations.Description: Tidal lagoons are enclosed areas of seawater that are partially enclosed by a natural or artificial barrier. They utilize the rise and fall of tides to generate electricity through turbines. Tidal lagoons can provide a more predictable and controllable source of tidal energy compared to other technologies.
relations.Subject: tidal lagoons

relations.Description: Tidal fences, also known as tidal barrages or tidal fences, are arrays of vertical axis turbines installed in a line across a tidal channel or river. They harness the kinetic energy of tidal currents to generate electricity. Tidal fences are suitable for locations with strong tidal flows.
relations.Subject: tidal fences

relations.Description: Tidal stream generators are devices that extract energy from the flow of tidal currents. They typically consist of underwater turbines or rotors that are anchored to the seabed or suspended in the water column. Tidal stream generators can be deployed in various configurations to maximize energy capture.
relations.Subject: tidal stream generators
